Definition: Intended to teach, often in a moralizing way
Usage: The professor’s didactic tone made the lecture feel like a sermon.

Definition: To assign to a lower rank or position
Usage: After the mistake, he was relegated to a less important role.

Definition: To bring under control or domination
Usage: The dictator sought to subjugate his people through fear.

Definition: Principles or beliefs held by a group
Usage: The tenets of democracy include freedom and equality.

Definition: To cause extreme damage or suffering
Usage: The hurricane wracked the coastal town.
The band’s eponymous album was their biggest hit.

Definition: A person who betrays or rebels against a group
Usage: He was labeled a renegade after leaving the political party.
She does calisthenics every morning to stay in shape.

Definition: A board used to communicate with spirits
Usage: They played with a Ouija board and got spooked.

Definition: To be caught off guard or unprepared
Usage: The company was flat-footed when the competitor launched first.

Definition: To persuade with flattery or deceit
Usage: He cajoled his friend into lending him money.

Definition: Difficult to find, catch, or achieve
Usage: The truth remained elusive despite the investigation.
His explanation was so nebulous that no one understood.
He was arrested for grand larceny after stealing a car.
Her tenacity helped her complete the marathon.

Definition: To worship or treat as a god
Usage: The ancient civilization deified their ruler.

Definition: To untangle or clarify something complicated
Usage: The detective unraveled the mystery in record time.
She railed about the unfair policies at the meeting.
It took chutzpah to ask for a raise on his first day.

Definition: Having the ability to see the future
Usage: The clairvoyant predicted the winning lottery numbers.
The politician’s speech sounded canned and insincere.

Definition: Having a second job in addition to a main job
Usage: He was fired for moonlighting as a bartender at night.
She made a brazen attempt to take credit for his work.
The professor was known for his erudite lectures.
His gluttony at the buffet was embarrassing.

Definition: Rude or not showing proper respect
Usage: His impertinent remarks angered the teacher.
The company was in arrears on its rent.
His sardonic smile made it clear he wasn’t impressed.

Definition: The beginning or origin of something
Usage: The genesis of the idea came from a casual conversation.
The newborn was swaddled in a soft blanket.

Definition: A person who cheats others out of money
Usage: The swindler tricked investors into giving him millions.
The novelty of the gadget wore off quickly.
The new laws were considered draconian by many.
The media vilified the politician after the scandal.
She was flummoxed by the complex math problem.

Definition: Special clothing or symbols of a group
Usage: The king’s regalia included a crown and a scepter.

Definition: Stated to be true but possibly not
Usage: His ostensible reason for leaving was a family emergency.
After the scandal, he became persona non grata in Hollywood.

Definition: A person who is ignorant or lacks knowledge
Usage: He called his opponent an ignoramus during the debate.

Definition: A person who wanders with no fixed home
Usage: The vagabond traveled from town to town.
She was emphatic that she would not change her mind.
He was often teased for being henpecked.
The company found itself in a financial quagmire.
He was dumbfounded when he won the lottery.
The teacher extolled her student’s efforts.
His speech was full of hackneyed phrases.
The lawyer tried to obfuscate the facts.
The unscrupulous businessman scammed his clients.
She was baffled by the complicated instructions.
The judge granted clemency to the first-time offender.
The inclemency of winter kept them indoors.
The novel was too cerebral for casual readers.
The art festival is a biennial event.
The contract included an indemnification clause.
These laws will impact posterity.
She faced a barrage of questions from reporters.

Definition: To worry unnecessarily about small things
Usage: He niggled over every minor detail in the project.
He barged into the meeting uninvited.
The pesky mosquitoes ruined our picnic.
He conceded that his opponent had a point.

Definition: Excessive pride or a clever idea
Usage: His conceit made him difficult to work with.
She spoke with candour about her past mistakes.
The factory emitted noxious fumes.
His canned response didn’t impress the interviewer.
The movie’s ending was poignant.

Definition: Having a spiritual or mysterious quality
Usage: The cathedral had a numinous atmosphere.

Definition: Long and drawn-out process of dying
Usage: The disease led to a protracted dying process.
Their efforts to stop the flood were futile.
He moseyed down the street, enjoying the evening.
She presented a cogent argument in court.
His callous remarks hurt her feelings.
The experiment had confounding results.
His argument was not tenable.
She took copious notes during the lecture.
He has a penchant for vintage cars.
I was remiss in not responding to your email.

Definition: Causing confusion or surprise due to being unexpected or difficult to explain
Usage: The experiment’s results were confounding to the researchers.
She was dumbfounded when she won the lottery.
He took copious notes during the lecture.
She has a penchant for collecting rare books.
I was remiss in failing to reply to your message.

Definition: Showing a lack of proper concern
Usage: His cavalier attitude towards deadlines frustrated his colleagues.

Definition: Overly concerned with minor details or academic rules
Usage: His pedantic corrections made the conversation tedious.
The passage of time is inexorable.
His hubris led to his downfall.
The rebels tried to wrest control from the government.

Definition: A continuous sequence in which adjacent elements are not noticeably different, but extremes are distinct
Usage: Intelligence exists on a continuum rather than as an absolute trait.

Definition: Dishonest practices or fraudulent medical treatments
Usage: The doctor was accused of quackery for selling snake oil remedies.
Even experts are fallible and make errors.

Definition: A mistaken belief based on unsound reasoning
Usage: The argument was based on a logical fallacy.
The sunset created fleeting moments of beauty.

Definition: Happening by chance in a happy or beneficial way
Usage: Their meeting at the airport was serendipitous.
My grandfather dislikes newfangled technology.
His reputation was marred by the scandal.
He suffered from several afflictions in his old age.
The villain was a loathsome nemesis to the hero.

Definition: People who are not experts in a specific field
Usage: The book explained quantum physics for laypeople.

Definition: Initiated or provoked an action or event
Usage: His speech instigated a wave of protests.
His infirmity prevented him from traveling.
His fortuitous encounter led to a new job opportunity.
The storm raged on with unabated intensity.

Definition: The responsibility or role in making discoveries
Usage: Scientists must take on the mantle of discovery.

Definition: The study of the disordered physiological processes associated with disease
Usage: Understanding pathophysiology is crucial for medical students.
The region suffered from various maladies due to poor sanitation.

Definition: Causes of great suffering or destruction
Usage: War and famine are scourges of civilization.

Definition: A long, complicated, and tedious process
Usage: Getting a visa was a rigamarole of paperwork.
Many believe artificial intelligence may one day become sentient.

Definition: Wild and noisy disorder or chaos
Usage: Pandemonium broke out when the fire alarm went off.
The battlefield was filled with carnage after the war.
His belligerent attitude started an argument.

Definition: Prone to sudden and unpredictable changes
Usage: The stock market is notoriously capricious.
His explanation was so circuitous that no one understood.
The ethical dilemma posed a real conundrum.
The illness debilitated him for weeks.

Definition: To recognize or distinguish something clearly
Usage: It was difficult to discern the truth from the rumors.

Definition: Lasting for a very short time
Usage: Beauty is ephemeral, but character lasts.

Definition: To use ambiguous language to avoid commitment
Usage: The politician equivocated when asked about taxes.

Definition: Extremely attentive to detail; hard to please
Usage: She’s fastidious about cleanliness in her home.
His flippant remark offended the professor.

Definition: Proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects
Usage: The disease had an insidious onset.
The villain's nefarious plot was finally uncovered.

Definition: A model of excellence or perfection
Usage: She is a paragon of kindness and generosity.

Definition: A person who flatters others for personal gain
Usage: The CEO surrounded himself with sycophants who never disagreed.

Definition: Bitter or harsh in speech or debate
Usage: The divorce proceedings became increasingly acrimonious.

Definition: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
Usage: The city streets were filled with the cacophony of honking cars.

Definition: Done secretly, especially for illicit purposes
Usage: The spies held a clandestine meeting in the abandoned warehouse.
Smoking has deleterious effects on health.
The hot weather enervated the marathon runners.
He wished he could expunge his embarrassing high school memories.
She showed great fortitude in overcoming her illness.

Definition: Tearful or tending to induce tears
Usage: The lachrymose movie left the audience in tears.

Definition: Harmful in a subtle or gradual way
Usage: Social media can have a pernicious effect on mental health.
She has a propensity for solving complex problems.

Definition: Not able to be defended or sustained
Usage: His argument was weak and ultimately untenable.
